DIV1.P: THE Honest Yorkshire-Man. A BALLAD FARCE. As it is Perform'd at the THEATRES With Universal Applause.
DIV1.Q: Nunc itaque & versus & caetera ludicra pono. HOR. Epist. I.
DIV1.P: LONDON: Printed for W. FEALES, at Rowe's Head, the Corner of Essex-street in the Strand; and the Book-sellers of London and Westminster. M.DCC.XXXV.

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE.
DIV1.L: THE Great, the Good, the Wise, in every Age,
Have made a moral Mirrour of the Stage;
While, to the Shame and Spite of tasteless Fools,
Terence still reigns a Classic in our Schools:
But now the DRAMA fears a sad Decline,
And peevish Hypocrites its Fall combine.
From Stage to Stage, behold our Author toss'd,
And but for you, his Genius crush'd and lost.
No Wilks, no Booth! his Labours to requite,
He here takes shelter, studious to delight.
But to our FARCE—It has a double Aim,
To honour Wedlock, and put Fools to Shame;
Folly and Prejudice, too near a Kin,
Supply pert Coxcombs with eternal Grin;
So infinitely stupid is their Mirth,
They'll ridicule one's very Place of Birth,
And cry, An honest Yorkshire-Man! a Wonder!
But let them shoot their Bolts, let Blockheads blunder.
The glorious Heroes of the Yorkshire Line,
To Times last Period shall in Annals shine;
While sland'ring Slaves, who would those Honours blot,
Shall unregarded live,—and die forgot,
Mean and unmanly is such partial Spite,
Averse to Nature's Laws, to Reason's Light;
All Fellow-Creatures, sure, should social be,
Nay, even to Brutes we owe Humanity.
Our Author does in Virtue's Cause engage,
In hopes to make her shine upon the Stage;
A modest Entertainment we intend,
Willing to please, yet fearful to offend;
Indulge us therefore, if you can't commend.

LIST.HEAD: At the THEATRE in the Hay-Market.
LIST.LABEL: Gaylove, a young Barrister, in Love with Arbella.
Muckworm, Uncle and Guar∣dian to Arbella.
Sapscull, a Country 'Squire, in∣tended for Arbella.
Slango, Servant to Gaylove, an Arch Fellow.
Blunder, Servant to Sapscull, a Clown.
Arbella, Niece to Muckworm, in Love with Gaylove.
Combrush, her Maid, a pert One.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, an Apartment in Muckworm's House, Arbella, Combrush.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR I. By Signior Porpora.

SP.SPEAKER: Arbella.
SP.L: GEntle, Cupid! seek my Lover,
Waft a thousand Sighs from me;
All my tender Fears discover,
Bid him haste!—
O bid him haste, and set me free.
Combrush!

SP.P: Ma'am.
No News from Gaylove yet?
Not a Tittle, Ma'am.
It quite distracts me.

And every Body else, Ma'am; for when you are out of Humour, one may as well be out of the World. Well! this Love is a strange Thing; when once it gets Possession of a young Lady's Heart, it turns her Head quite topsy-turvy, and makes her out of Hu∣mour with every Body—I'm sure I have Reason to say so.
Prithee leave you Nonsense, and tell me some∣thing of Gaylove.
All I can tell you, Ma'am, is, That he is stark staring Mad for Love of you. But this confound∣ed Uncle of yours—
What of him?
Has just receiv'd News of the Arrival of a rich Country 'Squire out of Yorkshire; which Country 'Squire is cut out for your Husband.
They that cut a Husband out for me, shall cut him out of better Stuff, I assure you.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR II. In vain, dear Chloe.

Q.L: Shall I stand still and tamely see,
Such Smithfield Bargains made of me?
Is not my Heart my own?
I hate, I scorn their clownish 'Squire,
Nor Lord, nor Duke, do I desire,

SP.P: Well said, Ma'am, I love a Woman of Spirit.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR III. Hark! away, tis the merry ton'd Horn.

Q.L: Why should Women so much be controul'd?
Why should Men with our Rights make so bold?
Let the Battle 'twixt Sexes be try'd,
We shall soon prove the strongest Side.
They'll bt make you their Game,

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE, a Street near the House.

SP.P: No Way to get at her?
The Devil a Bit, Sir; old Muckworm has cut off all Communication: But I have worse News to tell you yet.
That's impossible.
Your Mistress is to be married to another, and that quickly.
Married! You surprize me; to whom?
To 'Squire Sapscull, a Yorkshire Gentleman, of a very great Estate.

Confusion! Can she be so false? To Sapscull! I know him well, of Sapscull-Hall—I was born with∣in a Mile and a half of the place; his Father is the greatest Rogue in the County, the very Man I am now suing for what my late Brother mortgag'd to him, when I was Student at Cambridge. Is he not content to with∣hold my Right from me, but he must seek to rob me of the only Happiness I desire in Life?

DIV3.HEAD: AIR IV. The Charms of Florimel.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: 'Tis past the Pow'r of Tongue to tell,
The Love I bear my Arabell.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: I'd sooner take of Life farewel,

DIV3.P: Is there no way to prevent this Match? You were not us'd to be thus barren of Invention.

SP.P: Nor am I now, Sir; your humble Servant has invented already,—and such a Scheme!
How! which Way, dear Slango?

Why thus,—I must personate Arbella, (with this sweet Face) and you her Uncle, under which Disguises we may intercept the Country 'Squire, and get his Credentials; equipt with which—I leave you to guess the rest.
Happy Invention! Success attend it.

I can't say Amen; though I'd do any Thing to serve you. Do you know the Result, Sir? no less
than the Forfeiture of your dear Liberty. Have you forgot the Song of the Dog and the Bone?

DIV3.STAGE: Tune, When the bright God of Day.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Is plac'd in most wretched Condition:
And Death is his only Physician,
And Death is his only Physician.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: When summon'd by Love, or by Beauty;
But, where is the Bliss in
When Passion is prompted by Duty,
When Passion is prompted by Duty.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: A Bone he could leave at his Pleasure:
He's harrass'd and plagu'd beyond Measure,
He's harrass'd and plagu'd beyond Measure.

SP.P: I am now of a contrary Opinion: Vice looks so hateful, and Virtue so amiable in my Eye, especi∣ally as tis the ready Road to true Happiness, I am re∣solv'd to pursue its Paths. A regular Life, and a good Wife for me.

DIV3.P: N. B. The above Song is taken from Mr. Wors∣dale's Cure for a Scold, inserted here by his Permission, and very proper to be sung in this Place, by Slango, for the future.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR V. Answer to the above Song.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: It sure in a happy Condition;

LG.HEAD: II
LG.L: Yet dread some Disaster from Beauty?
Where Love mingles Pleasure with Duty,

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Than twenty good Wives who are saving;

SP.P: Wuns-lent! what a mortal big Place this same London is; ye mun ne'er see End on't, for sure; — Housen upon Housen, Folk upon Folk—one would admire where they did grow all of 'em.

Ay, Master, and this is nought to what you'll see an by; and ye go to Tower ye mun see great huge∣ous Ships as tall as Housen: Then ye mun go to Play∣housen, and there be no less nor six of 'em, a hopeful Company, o' my Conscience! There you'll see your comical Tragedies, and your Uproars, and Roaratori∣busses, and hear Fardinello, that sings Solfa better nor
our Minister Choir-Men: And more nor that, ye mun ya' your Choice of the prattiest Lasses, ye e'er set E'en on.
By th'Mess, and I'll be some body among 'em —so I will— but how mun we find out this same Sir Penurious Muckworm?
Ye mun look to Letter for that.
Lette says, G-r-o-z Groz-ve-n-e-r- near Grozveneer Square; but how mun ye know where this same Grozveneer Square is?
Why ye mun ask Ostler for that, he'll set you right for sure: For your London Ostlers are wiser by half than our Country Justasses.
Ay, Blunder, ev'ry thing's fine in London.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR VI. London is a fine Town.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: "For all the Streets are pav'd with Gold,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: "And there's your Lords and Ladies fine,

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: "And there's your Beaux, with powder'd Cloaths,

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: "While heaps of Gold are forc'd, God wot,

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: "And there's your Dames, of dainty Frames.

LG.HEAD: VI.
LG.L: "And if your mind be so inclin'd,

SP.P: Welcome to London, dear 'Squire Sapscull. I hope your good Father's well, and all at Sapscull-Hall.
Did ye e'er hear the like, Blunder? This old Gentleman knows me as well as I know myself.
Ay, Master, your Londoneers knows every thing.
I had Letters of your coming, and was resolv'd to meet you.
Pray, Sir, who may you be, an I may be so bold?
My Name, Sir, is Muckworm.
What Sir, Penurious Muckworm?
So they call me.
Sir, if your Name be Sir Penurious Muckworm, my Name is Samuel Sapscull, Jun. Esq Son of Sir Sa∣muel Sapscull of Sapscull-Hall i'th' East Riding o' Yorkshire.
Sir, I am no Stranger to your Family and Merit; for which Reason I sent for you to Town, to marry my Niece with 6000l. Fortune, and a pretty Girl in the Bargain.
Look ye there, Master!Aside to Sapscull.
Hold your Peace, you Blockhead.
But how may I be sure that you are the very Squire Sapscull I sent for? Have you no Letters, no Credentials?

Open the Portmantell, Blunder—Yes, Sir, ha'brought all my Tackle with me. Here, Sir, is a Letter from Father:—Gives a Letter.— And ere, Sir, are Deeds and Writings, to shew what you
mun ha' to trust to: And here, Sir, is Marriage-Settle∣ment, sign'd by Father, in fit Case young Gentlewoman And I likes one another.
Sir, she can't chuse but admire so charming a Person. There is but one Obstacle that I know of.
What may that be, an I may be so bold?
Your Habit, Sir, your Habit.
Why, Sir, 'twas counted wondrous fine in our Country last Parlementeering Time.
O, Sir, but 'tis old fashion'd now, and my Niece loves every Thing to the tip-top of the Mode. But if you'll go along with me, I'll equip you in an In∣stant.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR VII. Set by the Author.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: The Ladies shall languish for thee.

LG.HEAD: CHORUS.
LG.L: To live in thine own Country.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: With little more Brim than Lace
Will set off thy jolly broad Face.

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: Go get thee a Footman's Frock,
A Cudgel quite up to thy Nose,
And buckle thy Shoes at thy Toes.

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: And thou in the Box shalt drive.

LG.HEAD: V.
LG.L: Or enjoy the Delights of the Town.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR VIII. Set by the Author.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Ah what is Wealth or Treasure,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: O, thou for whom I languish,
And dost the same for me,

SP.P: Come, there's a good Girl, don't be in the Pouts, now.

I think it's enough to put any young Lady in the Pouts, to deny her the Man she likes, and force her to marry a great Loobily Yorkshire Tike. In short,
Sir, my Mistress dont like him, and won't have him— Nay, I don't like him; and tell you flat and plain she shan't have him.
Shan't have him, Mrs. Snap-dragon!
No, shan't have him, Sir—if I were she, I'd see who should force me to marry against my Will.
Was ever such an impudent Hussy; but I'll send you packing. Get out of my House, you saucy Baggage.
Sir, tho' you have the Care of my Estate, you have no Command over my Servants: I am your Ward, not your Slave; if you use me thus, you'll constrain me to chuse another Guardian.

Aside.A Gipsey! who taught her this Cun∣ning? I must hasten this Match, or lose 1000l. by the Bargain. To Arb. What a Bustle is here with a peevish Love sick Girl? Pray, Child, have you learnt Cupia's Catechism? Do you know what Love is?
Yes, Sir.—

DIV3.HEAD: AIR IX. set by the Author.

LG.L: Two fond Hearts in one unite.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: What are Titles, Pomp or Riches,
That false Joy which now bewitches,

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: But a chaste and constant Love,

SP.P: Sir, one 'Squire Sapscull out of Yorkshire, desires to speak with you.
I'm glad he's come—desire him to walk in

DIV3.STAGE: Servant goes out, and returns with Gaylove, dress'd in Sapscull's Cloaths.

SP.P: Sir, an your Name be Sir Penurious Muckworm.
Sir, I have no other,; may I crave yours?
Samuel Sapscull Jun. Esq at your Lordship's Service.
A very mannerly, towardly Youth, and a comely one, I assure you.To Arbella.
Pray, Sir, an I may be so bold, which of these two pretty Lasses is your Niece, and my Wife, that mun be.
What a brute is this? Before I'd have such a Wretch for a Husband, I'd die ten thousand Deaths.
Which do you like best, Sir?
Marry, and I were to chuse, I'd tak'em both.
Very courtly, indeed. I see the 'Squire's a Wag.
Both! I'll assure you, Sauce-box; the worst is too good for you.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR X. Gilly-Flow'r, gentle Rosemary.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Why how now, Sir Clown, dost set up for a Wit?
If here you should wed, you're as certainly bit,
As the Dew it flies over the Mulberry Tree.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: If such a fine Lady to Wife you should take,
Your Heart, Head, and Horns, shall as certainly ake,
As the Dew it flies over the Mulberry Tree.

SP.P: Insufferable Assurance! affront a Gentleman in my House! Never mind her, Sir; she's none of my Niece, only a pert Slut of a Chambermaid.
A Chamber-Jade! Lord, Lord, how brave you keep your Maidens here in London! Wuns-lent, she's as fine as our Lady Mayoress,
Ay, her Mistress spoils her; but follow me, Sir, and I'll warrant you we'll manage her, and her Mistress too.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XI. Set by the Author.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: O'er all my Steps and Passions:
No Bribe shall ever blind me;
An honest Lad you'll find me.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: And does for Business fit us;

DIV3.STAGE: All this Time Gaylove does his utmost to discover himself to Arbella, but she turns from him, and won't understand him.

SP.P: Well, an ye wunna see, I cannot help it, Good-by-t'-ye, forsooth; in the mean time, here's a Paper with something in it that will clear your Lady∣ship's Eye-sight.Throws down a Letter, and Exit, smiling
What can the Fool mean?
Taking up the Letter.Madam, as I live, here's a Letter from Mr. Gaylove.
This is surprising!

LETTER.P: THO' this Disguise is put on to blind old Muckworm, I hope it will not conceal from my dear Arbella, the Person of her ever constant

DIV3.P: Blind Fool that I was! I could tear my Eyesout.

SP.P: Lord, Ma'am, who the Duce could have thought it had been Mr. Gaylove. Well, our Maiden-heads certainly stood in our Lights this Bout.
Hold your Prattle; I have great hopes of this Enterprize, however, it carries a good Face with it; but whether it succeeds or no, I must love the dear Man that ventures so hard for my Sake.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XII. Set by the Author.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: That Man who best can Danger dare
Is most deserving of the Fair;
The Bold and Brave we Women prize
The whining Slave we all despise.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Let Coxcombs flatter, cringe and lie,
Pretend to languish, pine, and die;
Such Men of Words my scorn shall be,
The Man of Deeds is the Man for me.

SP.P: My Mistress is intirely in the right on't.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XIII. I had a pretty Lass, a Tenant of my own.

Q.L: But to a Lad that's clever,

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Sapscull drest a-la-mode de Petit Maitre, Blun∣der in a rich Livery, with his Hair tuck'd up, and powder'd behind.

SP.P: Mess, Master, how fine ye be; marry, be∣lieve me, an ye were at Sapscull-Hall, I dare say, Sir Samuel himself would hardly know ye.

Know me, marry, I don't know myself.— Surveying himself.—I'm so fine: And thou art quite another sort of a Creature too.—Turns Blunder about. —Well, talk what ye list o' Yorkshire, I say there's nought like London; for my Part, I don't care an I ne'er see the Face of Sapscull-Hall agen.
What need ye, an ye getten 6000l. with young Gentlewoman; besides, Vather has ty'd Estate fast enough to ye;—An I were as ye, I'd e'en bide here, and live as lofty as the best o' 'em.

P.Q: “Ay, Blunder, so I will, and see Bartledom ”Fair too.
“That you mun not; for I did hear 'em talk, at the Green Man at Barnet, as how the May'r had ”cry'd it down.

“How! cry'd down Bartledom Fair! What a murrain is London good for then? I wou'dn't bide
”here and they'd gi't me—I thought to have had such Fun now—

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XIV. Bartholemew-Fair,
DIV3.STAGE: To them, a Servant, well dress'd.

SP.P: Gentlemen, I come from Sir Penurious Muck∣worm, I am his Servant, and wait on purpose to con∣duct you to Mrs. Arbella's Apartment.
Servant! Waunds, why you're finer nor your Master.
O, Sir that's nothing in London.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENE, an Apartment.
DIV2.STAGE: Slango representing Arbella, Servant introducing Sap∣scull and Blunder.

SP.P: Well, Forsooth, you know my Business; few Words are best among Friends — Is it a Match, or no? Say Ay, and I'll second you.
A very compendious way of wooing, truly. Aside. I hope you'll spare a Maiden's Blushes, Sir; but Lard Gad you are too quick upon me.
I means to be quicker yet, ay marry, and make thee quick too, afore I ha'done with thee.
I protest, Sir, you put me to such a Nonplus, I don't know what to say.
Ne'er heed; Parson shall teach thee what to say. For my Part, I ha' con'd my Lesson afore-hand.
But will you love me?

Love thee? Lord, Lord, I loves thee better than I does my Bay-Filley; did you ne'er see her, For∣sooth? Od, she's a dainty Tit, and sure I am,—I loves her better nor I do nown Father.— Blunder, run and set a Parson.
Mr. Blunder may save himself that Trouble, Sir, I have provided one already.
Why then let's make haste, dear sweet Honey, for I long till its over.Exeunt.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XV. Set by the Author.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: My Hearts Delight, my Soul's Desire;
Than King to be of India's Shore.

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: For every Woman were there Three,
And in the World, no Man but me;
I'd single you from all the rest
To sweet on Life, and make me blest.

SP.L: Well, I never was so deceiv'd in my Life!
How could you clown it so naturally?

SP.P: What is it I would not do, for your dear Sake? But, I intreat you, let's lay hold of this Opportunity, and put it out of Fortune's Power ever to di∣vide us.
What would you have me do?
Leave all to me. I have left Combrush to a∣muse your Uncle, while a Fellow-Collegiate of mine, who is in Orders, waits in the next Room to finish the rest.
Do what you will with me: For in short, I don't know what to do with myself.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XVI. The Nymph that undoes me.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Arb.Let Prudes and Coquets their Intentions conceal;
With Pride, and with Pleasure, the Truth I re∣veal;
You're all I can wish, and all I desire;
So fix'd is my Flame it ne'er can expire,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Gay.Let Rakes, and Libertines, revel and range;
Possess'd of such Treasure, what Mortal would change;
You're the Source of my Hopes, The Spring of my Joy,
A Fountain of Bliss that never can cloy.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XVII. By Mr, Handel.

Q.L: When two Hearts like ours unite?
When our Fondness knows no Measure,
And no Bounds our dear Delight.

SP.P: Well! I forgive you: This last Action has made amends for all find a Chamber-maid is Prime Minister in Matrimonia airs—And you say, they are quite loving.
Fond, fond, Sir, as two Turtles! But I beg you wou'd not disturb 'em.
By no Means; let 'em have their Love out, pretty Fools! I shall be glad, however, to see some of their little Fondnesses: But tell me seriously, how do you like the 'Squire?
Oh! of all Things, Sir; and so does my Mistress, I assure you.
How that Scoundrel, Gaylove, will be disap∣pointed!
He'll be ready to hang himself, (about her Neck)Aside.
They'll make Ballads upon him.
I have made one already, and will sing it if you please.
With all my Heart.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XVIII. A Beggar got a Beadle.

LG.HEAD: I
LG.L: Her Uncle to prevent the same,
Did all that in him lay,
For which he's very much to blame,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: But such Contraries in a Bed,
To see a Lady bright and gay,

SP.P: I dont like this Song.
Then you don't like Truth, Sir.
What! d'ye mean to affront me?
Wou'd you have me tell a Lye, Sir?
Get out of my House, you Baggage.
I only stay to take my Mistress with me; and see, here she comes.
So, Sir; you have deceiv'd me: but I'll pro∣vide you a Wedding-Suit; a fine long Chancery Suit, before ever you touch a Penny of her Fortune.
Sir, if you dare embezzle a Farthing, I'll provide you with a more lasting Garment; a curious Stone-Doublet: You have met with your Match, Sir; I have studied the Law, ay, and practis'd it too.
The Devil take you, and the Law together—
——Hey Day! Who in the Name of Wonder have we got here?
Only 'Squire Sapscull, his Bride, and boobily Man.
Come, my Dear! hold up your Head like a Man, and let him see what an elegant Husband I have got.
Ay; and let 'em see what a dainty Wife my Master has gotten.
Here's a pow'r of fine Folk, sweet honey Wife! pray, who may they be?
This, Sir, is Sir Penurious Muckworm—
No Honey! I fear you are mistaken. Sir Pe∣nurious is another guise sort of a Man; an I mistake not, he's more liker yon same Gentleman.
Ay, so he is, Master.
That same Gentleman was Sir Penurious Muckworm, some time ago, but now he's chang'd to George Gaylove, Esq.
At your Service, Sir.
And who's yon fine Lady?
My Wife, Sir, and that worthy Knight's Niece.
Your Wife! and that Knight's Niece? why who a murrain have I gotten then?
My Man, Slango; and I wish you much Joy.
Your Man, Slango! what have I married a Man, then?
If you don't like me, my Dear, we'll be di∣vorc'd this Minute.
My Dear, a Murrain take such Dears! Where's my Writings? I'll ha' you all hang'd for Cheats.

You had better hang yourself for a Fool. Go Home, Child, go Home, and learn more Wit. There's your Deed of Settlement; but as for the Wri∣tings, they happen to be mine, and kept fraudulently from me by your Father, to whom they were mort∣gag'd by my late Brother. The Estate has been clear these three Years. Send your Father to me and I'll talk to him. This is but Tit for Tat, young Gentle∣man. Your Father wanted to get my Estate from me, and I have got the Wife he intended for you. All's fair, Sir.
I say all's foul, and a damn'd Cheat; and so I'll make it appear.Exit in a Rage,
Do your worst, Sir, you can't unmarry us.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XIX. Set by the Author.

SP.L: Now Fortune is past it's severest,
My Passion, of Mortal's sincerest,
Kind Heaven has repaid in my Dearest;
What Gifts can it greater bestow?
Tru Love shall thro' Destiny guide us,
Still constant whatever betide us,
There nothing but Death shall divide us,
So faithful a Fondness we'll show.
By Cupid and Hymen united,
By Danger no longer affrighted,
We'll live in each other delighted,
The greatest of Blessings below.

SP.P: What mun I do? I mun ne'er see Father's Face again.

Never fear, 'Squire, I'll set all to rights; tho' your Father's my Enemy, I'm not yours: My House shall be your Home, till I have reconcil'd you to your Father; and for the Honour of Yorkshire, I'll see you shan't be abus'd here.
Say ye so, Sir? Then I do wish you much Joy with all my Heart.
Ay, and so does Blunder too.
Well, sin I see you be so happy in a Wife, I'll not be long without one I assure you.
You can't be happier than I wish you.

DIV3.HEAD: AIR XX. Set by the Author.

LG.HEAD: I.
LG.L: Gayl.Come learn by this ye Batchelors,
Come learn by this ye Batchelors,
When once ye come to serious Thought,
When once ye come to serious Thought,

LG.HEAD: II.
LG.L: Arb.Come learn by this ye Maidens fair,
You're better in a Husband's Arms,

LG.HEAD: III.
LG.L: He eats and drinks at all Mens Cost,

LG.HEAD: IV.
LG.L: So when the Fox cou'dn't reach the Grapes,
He cry'd they all were sow'r,

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE, Spoken by Mrs. CANTRELL the Three First Nights.

LG.L: MArriage of humane social States the best,
Has been too long the Coxcomb's common Jest,
While worn-out Reprobates, and silly Boys,
Unworthy as unknowing of its Joys,
Loudly exclaim against the Nuptial Life,
Extol the Harlot, but cry down the Wife.
To such Extreams their saucy Sneers are carry'd,
One wou'd conclude their Mothers dy'd unmarry'd.
To Virtue's Glory see the Good and Great,
Set bright Examples of the Marriage State.
Behold our Sovereign Lord compleatly blest,
And in his Queen, of all that's good possest:
All Virtues, all Perfections, splendid shine.
Tho' plac'd in the Sublimity of Life,
Still a fond Mother, still a tender Wife,
Pattern of Virtue, and connubial Love,
A finish'd Copy of the blest Above.
Ladies, I now must plead the Poet's Cause,
He's your old Champion—shall he have Applause?
If Value for our Sex can recommend,
He's known by all to be a Woman's Friend.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE, Spoken after the Third Night, in the Summer-Season, at the Haymarket.
DIV1.L: WE see with Pleasure the indulgent Town,
Wont let their veteran Bard be quite cast down:
Spight of Stage-Tyrants, and their partial Scoff,
He stood his Tryal, and came nobly off.
I told him, if the Ladies did befriend him,
He'd gain his Point, Success would sure attend him,
This Little House, this Season of the Year,
The Town so thin, might give the Man some Fear:
But full of Hopes, he follow'd Fortune's Call,
Better to Act it here, than not at all.
'Tis a new Practice, tho' I see no Reason,
To shut the Stage up all the Summer Season.
Our very Candle-snuffer's Winter's Pay,
Will scarce support him in a Summer's Day.
Why do our angry Grandsire's vent their Rage,
And persecute so fierce their once lov'd Stage,
Lost to all Taste of customary Joys,
These old Men quite forget they once were Boys.
FIELDING and OATES may pray for London' Mayr,
He's granted them a Holiday this Fair.
Then hither bring your Daughters, Friends and Spouses;
We'll find Diversion, so you'll find full Houses.
We don't pretend the Tip-top to excel,
But 'tis some kind of Merit to mean well.
